claim: Many people think that Mozart composed Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star, but no recorded composer exists for this tune.

supporting.text: Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star is based on a French folk melody called 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman,' which predates Mozart's variations on the tune.

attacks.text: Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star is based on a French folk melody called 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman,' which predates Mozart's variations on the tune.
Mozart's variations on the tune are widely recognized and often mistakenly attributed as the original composition due to their popularity.
The attribution of folk melodies to famous composers is common in music history due to the lack of formal records for traditional tunes.

supporting.text: Mozart composed a set of variations (K. 265/300e) on the melody of 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman,' but he did not create the original tune.

attacks.text: Mozart composed a set of variations (K. 265/300e) on the melody of 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman,' but he did not create the original tune.
The melody of 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman' is virtually identical to 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star,' leading many to conflate Mozart's variations with the original composition.
Historical records show that 'Ah! vous dirai-je, Maman' predates Mozart and was a popular French folk song, making attribution to Mozart incorrect.

supporting.text: The melody of Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star has been traced back to at least the mid-18th century, long before Mozart's variations were written in 1781 or 1782.

attacks.text: The melody of Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star has been traced back to at least the mid-18th century, long before Mozart's variations were written in 1781 or 1782.
Mozart's variations on the tune are widely recognized and often mistakenly attributed as the original composition due to his fame.
Historical records show that the melody was already popular in France before Mozart's time, further supporting its pre-existing origin.
The lack of a recorded composer for the original tune does not necessarily mean it predates Mozart; it could simply be lost to history.

supporting.text: Historical musicology attributes the original melody to anonymous folk origins rather than to any specific composer.

attacks.text: Historical musicology attributes the original melody to anonymous folk origins rather than to any specific composer.
The melody was popularized by Mozart's variations, leading many to mistakenly attribute the original composition to him.
Mozart's variations are so well-known that they overshadow the folk origins, reinforcing the misconception.
The lack of a recorded composer for the original tune does not necessarily imply it was anonymous; records may simply be lost.
